title.narrative: DCCN Stateless Children and Women Groups Empowerment Project 2016-2020

description.narrative: The Stateless Children and Women Groups Empowerment Project under Development Center for Children and Community Network supports stateless students and stateless women with approximate number of 3,748 and 2,198 people respectively including indirect target groups of 128,562 stateless people in 3 provinces of Chiang Mai, Mae Hong Son and Tak. The stateless students and women are having problems on personal legal status and citizenship, making them not equally access to rights to education, health care, travel, scholarship and decent work. Major causes of the problems are their lack of knowledge and understanding on personal legal status verification processes, ineffective enforcement of the law by authorities and unavailability of necessary law and policies. The project aims to get their names registered with 13 digits identification number in order to access the government services such as rights to education, health care, travel and decent work and that they are equally treated.  The project objectives are that the students and their families receive the highest legal status and are able to access their rights. The project expects the students including their families to obtain legal status including nationality for a minimum number of 300-500 persons per year in 4 target districts including other register offices. Activities include data survey and development, training for stateless student’s volunteers and women groups, mobile counseling services, legal clinic, stateless women group empowerment, coordination with authorities in relevant district offices, network building at targeted communities and policy advocacy. Focus thematic areas are statelessness and personal legal status and citizenship and women empowerment. Other stakeholders include government sectors such as district office, NGO’s such as legal status networks.
This project mainly contributes to results within Empowerment of human rights defenders. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020
